title: The Desert Sun and The Asbury Park Press receive 2019 National Edward R. Murrow Awards
text:
The Desert Sun and The Asbury Park Press were named 2019 National Edward R. Murrow Award winners last week.

The Radio Television Digital News Association has been honoring outstanding accomplishments in broadcast and digital journalism with the Edward R. Murrow Awards, among the most prestigious in news, since 1971.

The Asbury Park Press won the National Murrow Award for investigative reporting for the series “Protecting the Shield." Press reporters spent two years investigating police misconduct across the state of New Jersey, and the process involved examining more than 30,000 pages of legal and public documents. Their reporting resulted in the implementation of statewide reform to combat police misbehavior in the future. These changes include mandatory random drug testing for all officers and the establishment of an "early warning” system to find bad cops.

"Winning the Murrow award not only recognizes our staff's incredible dedication and perseverance in exposing the truth about bad, even deadly, cops in the state, but it helps shine a very bright light on an issue that has to be addressed by lawmakers," Press Executive Editor Paul D'Ambrosio said. "The series has prompted important changes, but more needs to be done."

The series also won the national Silver Gavel Award from the American Bar Association which honors work that helps the public’s understanding of the law and legal system.

The Desert Sun won the National Murrow Award for excellence in innovation for the “Poisoned Cities, Deadly Border” investigative series, which uncovered a pattern of unchecked pollution on the U.S.-California border. The four-part series examines the pollution of the New River which flows from Mexicali across the border into the United States and its effects on the environment and people’s health. The investigation was conducted over a two-year period by writer Ian James and photographer Zoë Meyers of The Desert Sun and led by the Arizona Republic/azcentral.com executor editor Greg Burton, who was executive editor of The Desert Sun when the project began. The project was done in collaboration with the Arizona Republic and USA TODAY and, features photos, videos, 360 videos and interactive graphics. All the stories in the series were published in both English and Spanish. as well.

In addition, The Desert Sun won this year’s Society of Professional Journalists’ New America award for “Poisoned Cities, Deadly Border.” ProPublica chose the Arizona Republic/azcentral as one of six winners of its ongoing Local Reporting Network as well. This project aids investigative journalism in newsrooms at the local and regional level across the country by providing funding and expertise in research, data, engagement, video and design.

“This project is border focused, but universal in human toll and drama,” said Greg Burton. “I am so proud of the collaborative effort by teams from The Desert Sun, The Arizona Republic, and USA TODAY NETWORK to shed light on this issue that is affecting so many lives.”

“The RTDNA National Edward R. Murrow Awards recognize local and national news stories that uphold our Code of Ethics, demonstrate technical expertise and exemplify the importance and impact of journalism as a service to the community. Winning a Murrow Award means that a news organization has provided exemplary public service to its viewers, listeners and readers,” said Dan Shelley, RTDNA executive director, during the announcement this week.

The Murrow Awards will be presented to the winners at Edward R. Murrow Awards Gala on October 14 in New York.
